comments.commentBody:
"These are the Wall Street geniuses who, five years ago, on a Thursday afternoon, notified the government that, unless they received an eight hundred billion dollar bailout by Monday morning, no questions asked, the entire global financial system would collapse. "

Is that a fact? When I read through "Too Big To Fail, On The Brink, The Anglides Commission Report" I do not recall seeing that. What I recall was letting Lehman Bros. Fail, froze up the credit system. Hank Paulson had to convince Bush to get congress to allow the Fed to keep the banks liquid.

Basically only five major institutions were involved, Bear Stearns, Lehman, AIG, Citi Bank, and Merrill Lynch, all of whom had created CDOs, SIVs, and other exotic investment plans that other banks and financial institutions bought.

What allowed that to happen was the Gramm-Leach-Blily Act, which allowed commercial bank and investment banks to merge.

It does no one any good to misstate the cause of the financial crisis, it does not lead to preventing the same from happening again. It may feel good to castigate bankers and the wealthy, but it is no productive.
Why did you decide to attend Tufts?  Do you think it's worth that price tag, which, by the way, is a lot more per year than a lot of full-time, permanent faculty make?

Good ol' France.
We the French will sell the Syrians automatic weapons, tanks and missiles to murder people, but as the chemical weapons aren't French - they must not be used and we must intervene. Typical.

Almost everyone agrees that there are no good outcomes. Opinions differ in what is the least bad option - It is not always "no action".

Two years ago, most people thought Assad to be less of an evil than Khadaffi. Unlike the menacing evil in Libya, the evil in Syria seemed more manageable or tolerable. So the world hesitated as the death toll slowly climbed up. Obama hesitated when his "red line" was crossed. Now that the scope of the disaster has surpassed the most pessimistic predictions, do we still think inaction at earlier times were wise?

Look at the "good reasons" given for inaction:
- Russia and China were trying to "prevent the bloodbath in Libya to happen again in Syria". Look at their proud accomplishment.

- US delayed sending weapons to the rebels, so that (a) to not encourage more fighting, (b) to avoid making Islamic foundamentalist grow stronger, and (c) to not get into another foreign adventure. Are these achieved? Are we certain that nothing worse will happen in Syria, or that we will do nothing no matter what?

Many of those against intervention in Syria were happy when Iraq war started and unhappy for the intervention in Libya. I was against Iraq war, enthusiastic about Libya intervention, and thinks that it's wrong to not intervene in Syria.

The frog has been sitting in hot water for a long time while the water gets hotter. There have never been a good time to jump. All we do is to pray that the water will not get hotter.

The problem is there are no good outcomes.

As usual, Americans posting here are clueless about history.

The Russians support Assad not because they are evil, but because Assad is the protector of the Syrian Orthodox Church. Russia has always supported Orthodox Christians in the Ottoman lands. Cynically, yes, as an instrument of their expansionist foreign policy, but there is an emotional hold on the Russian population for this position.

Tolstoy has scenes in Anna K. of young men rushing off to fight with the Serbs in their rebellion against the Turks (Tolstoy paints them as young hotheads and the town drunks, but their train tickets are paid by wealthy patrons), and that was back in 1870.

The Russians are not going to change in this respect.

From the US point of view, most of the rebel groups are Sunni Islamists, precisely the types of people like the Taliban who neither represent our values nor our 'interests'. Giving them a leg up against the Assad regime would gain us nothing and make the Shia hate us even more.

So its not that Obama is 'weak', he is just calculating. Our elites will intervene whenever they see a significant interest in it (or if the genocide becomes scandalous enough, as in Kosovo).

France feels a lingering responsibility just as the Brits did with Iraq, because after WWI France and Britain created these two Frankenstein states as 'protectorates' and divided them between them. Syria belonged to the French.

So let them handle it.

Either I've assumed, or actually read, that the chemical gas involved was sarin, which I understand is odorless and colorless. But several eye-witnesses have described a variety of strong smells – rotten eggs, vinegar, cooking gas. Does this mean the gas involved might have been something other than sarin? Or is sarin sometimes mixed with other gases that have a distinctive smell?

Persistent failure to act is, itself, a very public action with its own ramifications and will never exculpate the desultory.  Witness the vilification of the United States by Egyptians of all factions, for instance, and the fact that failure to have any policy at all there does not in any way prevent the situation from getting worse; nor does it shield the country from the consequences of its inactions.

Pres. Assad can expect to use chemical weapons with impunity because it is extremely likely that the West will conveniently hide behind the UN Security Council's refusal to act decisively, which in turn is guaranteed by Russia and China.

The inspectors do not exactly have free reign, and will only be permitted to go to sites that the Syrian government invites them to.   Thus, they are not an issue.  Nor, for that matter, is the likely reaction of the United States, which will be to express concern and make offended noises but to suborn its foreign policy to the Security Council in this case so it will be conveniently prevented from taking any action that they actually had no will to take.

It is absurd to wait for confirmation. Video has been shown that strongly indicates that the deaths were due to Sarin gas, which is known to be in the Syrian military inventory. It is time France, UK, and the USA act jointly to make an all out attack on Syria, especially on its stockpiles of Sarin gas and any other no longer permitted by international law gas weapons. U. S. forces are equipped to do this mission, which they can execute while the UK and France coordinate with the USA to bomb all of the offensive weapons of the Syrian military. If the soldiers responsible can be captured they need to be sent directly to the International War Crimes Tribunal for trial and prison or execution.

If the US fails to act now, Obama's words are worthless and he has no sense of humanitarian responsibility. There are no other ways these hundreds of gas victims cold have died. That doesn't mean though we have to actually side with Syrian rebels who still need to win the fight on their own in a fair fight, instead of the current unbalanced one.

We (or the French) should

1. immediately tell Assad that, if he doesn't grant safe passage to UN personnel already in the country for as long as it takes them to determine whether chemical weapons were used in the East Damascus attack on Wednesday and, if so, where they came from, we (or the French) solemny promise to cruise-missle the bejeesus out of his key government buildings and military installating

2. If he doesn't budge, demonstrate that we're not pikers by delivering on said solemn promise.

3. Immediately after that repeat the promise.

4 Repeat steps 1 - 3 as many times as is necessary.

At this point, think damage control.

Does it really suit the United States if Iran gains greater influence with a rump Syrian state which is clearly dependent upon the military support of Hizbollah to maintain integrity, and thus even more likely to side with Iran out of necessity?

Does it really suit the United States if the war festers, destabilizing neighboring countries with increased numbers of refugees and an increased number of related attacks between sympathizers of varying factions?

Does it really suit the United States if the president chooses to undermine all his remaining credibility by persisting in ignoring his own publicly declared "red lines"?

Does it really suit the United States to show that while the United States will *talk* about liberty and rights, when push comes to shove it'll stand aside leaving virulent extremists as the only sources of significant assistance?

Does it really suit the United States to imply that it will suborn its own interests and policies to a Chinese or Russian veto?

It's not like intervention would be pretty, or that it would lead to a "good" outcome. However, it's not like the situation will neatly resolve itself to the benefit of the United States if it fails to take any action, either; instead, it will probably get catastrophically worse from the point of view of the United States (let alone Syrian civilians). The problem is how to mitigate the damage that will happen c/o previous inaction.

There are other options, such as tilting the balance in order that the resulting situation is still an improvement.

We don't need to create a perfect, stable Syria. Nor should we put Syrian interests ahead of our own. However, it is probably better for the United States that it not only regain some credibility that Pres. Obama has shredded with his previous reluctance to intervene, but also to ensure that the resulting situation does not lead to a rump Syrian state blatantly subject to Iranian authority. Turmoil with weakened Iranian interests and some factional strife between rebel movements is better for our situation than turmoil with a new Iranian protectorate.
Haven't we learned?  Best to stay out of the conflict.  Stop trying to be the world's policeman.  Save taxpayer dollars and American lives
Saudi Arabia,  United Arab Emirates and other Sunni Moslems.
Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and the United Arab Emirates are supplying the insurgents with money and weapons.
My question is who is funding the opposition with guns and weapons

"The enemy of my enemy" strategy didn't work out so well with Islamist groups last time (OBL). I don't blame anyone for not wanting to get involved in Syria's civil war.
That being said, being the de facto (political, economic and military) leader of the planet does bring with it certain responsibilities. Not the least of which is the moral obligation to protect those who cannot protect themselves. I truly hope this time around the US works in concert with other like-minded nations and organizations to assist where assistance is required.
This is a classic no-win situation.

A convenient oversimplification.  As you may know, Iran and Russia already constitute "a solution imposed from outside" since the former is providing Bashar al-Assad its elite Guardians of the Revolution troops while Russia is providing him advanced missile systems.  In this context, doesn't  the people of Syria deserve some military assistance?

I regretfully believe that the only reasonable course of action for our government is to keep as far away from this civil war as we can get. To become involved once again in the Middle East with more than offers of humanitarian help is to jump out of the cold frying pan back into the burning fire where we will be stuck again with nothing in the end to show for it but dead Americans.

Let them continue killing each other until they either become satiated or there is no one left to kill. It just should not be our problem.

Two words: Sykes-Picot. If the French and the British want to have another go at undoing the mess they created in 1916, they are welcome to try. I doubt that the outcome will be any better.

Horrible as the mayhem is, the least bad solution is to let them go on killing each other. A solution imposed from outside will not work, and re-colonization is impossible.

Why not negotiate with the Syrian government to allow the people they hate so much,  to fly out of Syria to the safety of various countries. We have taken refugees in the past, as have other countries ; why not now?

The torture of an American captured by Syrian rebels(reported in a current ny times article) is another reason we should stay out of this conflict. the rebels have been co opted by islamist terrorists.
When I saw the videos, the first thing that came to my mind was Bhopal. This looks a lot more like an industrial accident than a rocket attack.

All true but I disagree with your conclusion .Chemical weapons use against civilians cannot be tolerated. Our retaliation should be sufficient to let Assad know that chemical weapons use will cost him far more than it will gain him from a military perspective.

Although I don't support the horrors perpetrated by Assad, it is clear to me that he is in no danger of being overthrown and it would be stupid of the US to take the side of the losers, chemical weapons or not. Also, the people opposing him are inextricably tied  to radical Islamist groups who will never support the US and in fact will target the US. If these groups overthrow Assad, there is not a snowball's chance in hell that they will support the US even if the US assists them.

Al;
You would be kidding thinking of France as a neutral state in this particular conflict!!! Were they sleeping for the last 3 years and 'woke up' with a NIGHTMARE t!!! French role like the rest of the 'west' was disgusting and pathetic in Syrian conflict.

Absolutely hypocritical and duplicitous!!!

The Syrian government is known to have large stockpiles of chemical weapons and has already been determined to have used them. Every account of chemical weapons use of which I'm aware has been directed people in rebel areas, a rather improbably strategy if the rebels are using these weapons that they don't happen to have.

So is a false flag operation impossible? No, and it has to be ruled out. But it's unlikely and investigators will no doubt be able to rule it out -- no signature is required, in a case like this you can interview people who were present and ask where the rockets came from -- not to mention that there may be national security resources that can't be disclosed but would contribute to a conclusion.

The question remains, how do we tell who used the chemical weapons?  Its obvious that a nerve agent was released given the sudden Atropine deficiencies in area hospitals, but are the UN scientists capable at this point of pinpointing the source of the attacks?   I believe the Syrian government's response will tell us more than anything else. There is no database as of yet that will tell us exactly where the nerve agent came from.  Anthrax and other nasty bacteria-based biological threats each have a chemical signature that can be traced to different labs, but can the same be said of these agents? A thorough investigation of the methods used and who the attacks were directed at could also be useful, but I would not put it past some fanatical groups to direct an attack upon themselves to get the weapons and support needed to "win.".  I cannot help but wonder because as soon as the US drew a "red line" with regards to chemical agents, they were used.  It was a serious mistake of foreign policy to make a statement like that.  It's akin to saying "If you want us to help you with everything--here is what has to happen."  I encourage France to take the lead as they are viewed by the world as one of the more neutral nations in this particular fiasco.

Eric, appeasing Putin and the other thugs of the world, will only get us more thuggery, and more innocents slaughtered, and an all round less hospitable world.
If you really give a hoot at all about peace and prosperity and anything else that is good, you might consider that.
There are some things that come along where stands have to be made. And if a stand isn't made, the consequences are almost always worse than what was walked away from.
This is one of those cases.
Please everybody, read the comments above of "learninghappenseverywhere". a victim of appeasement who knows of what they speak.
All the thousands who could have been saved, maybe even millions, including who knows how many of the half-million we lost, if only people had stood up to that era's thugs earlier.
I guess there is no problem so great that killing someone isn't the simplest solution.

I'm wondering if the advances in computer technology and communications reduced the friction in the markets and the flow of capital into and out of trouble spots, pulling capital more broadly, and flowing more easily.

This and the centralization of capital, so fewer people could unleash more. Seems like a new world.

My story is much like yours. Only two big differences. One, when I was young I really wanted children and had lots of maternal feelings. But, much like you, marriage ending and wanting to make sure later marriage was stable before having children, I didn't want to start that late. I still have a nurturing nature. Second main difference it that I am well past menopause and have no regrets.

I've asked all of my childless friends past menopause if they have regretted no children. They have not. Most of them have been married a very long time.
